values.alignmentText: Shanghai's riverfront parks soften the skyline, but air and water quality vary; weekend trips for clean air are part of our plans.
Shanghai's flood/typhoon risk is mitigated by seawalls but climate threats persist; active planning and insurance are prudent for a family.
Shanghai has hot, humid summers and damp winters; spring and autumn are mild, but high humidity requires flexible outdoor plans.
Shanghai PM2.5 averages ~35–40 µg/m³ with seasonal smog; monitor AQI and use purifiers before outdoor play for the kids.
Shanghai, China faces typhoons and Yangtze floods seasonally; strong urban prep and flood controls cut impact, but keep emergency kits ready.
Shanghai spring ranges roughly 12–23°C with frequent showers. Layer up for the kids; many days are mild enough for outdoor parks and short bike rides.
Shanghai summers commonly hit 33–35°C with high humidity. Reliable A/C and planned indoor breaks keep the family comfortable.
Shanghai autumn is mild: Sep ~28°C (82°F), Oct ~20°C (68°F); occasional rain showers and layers needed.
Shanghai winters hover roughly 0-9°C (32-48°F). Damp chill with sparse central heating makes space heaters common.
Shanghai beaches like Jinshan are usable but water quality is murky. Expats often travel to Zhoushan or Hainan for clearer water.
Shanghai beaches run 25-28°C in summer; shoulder months ~20°C, so swimmable for part of the year with light protection.
Shanghai offers well-kept city parks; for real nature, plan weekend trips to Moganshan or Huangshan beyond the city.
Shanghai's ¥2,690/mo minimum wage covers basics but falls short for a 2-adult/2-child family after housing and schooling costs.
Shanghai software seniors earn roughly CNY 420k–780k (~$60k–$112k) plus bonuses; strong locally but below top Western packages.
Shanghai has steady .NET demand in finance and tech, but Mandarin fluency and long hours limit expat entry; pursue remote roles and local grants.
Ruby roles in Shanghai are scarce; Sarah should target remote or multinational teams, or pivot to more in-demand stacks locally.

Shanghai's robust, diversified economy offers startup support, steady jobs, and safety nets that help families weather shocks.

China frames itself as a confident rising power, with Shanghai as a hub. Centralized governance may clash with the family's preference for pluralistic media.
In Shanghai, China, views of neighbors are cordial on trade but shaped by media disputes; public sentiment blends cooperation with cautious skepticism.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: In Shanghai, neighbors value China's role as a regional hub for trade and tech. However, occasional policy disagreements temper the view.

Shanghai (CN) operates under single-party rule with limited political participation and restricted civil liberties; civic checks are weak.
